questions.question_text:
A customer wants to use Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) for storing application backups which can be stored for months, but retrieved immediately based on business needs.
Which OCI storage service can be used to meet this requirement?

discussion.content: b is correct

I also think the B option is correct because Object Storage for data to which you need fast, immediate, and frequent access. Data accessibility and performance justifies a higher price to store data in the Object Storage tier.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Concepts/objectstorageoverview.htm

Explanation: This link https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/blockvolumebackups.htm provides information about the Type of Backup, which is in our case is Block Volume Backup. 
But, the type of storage used to store Block Volume backups is Object Storage. It can be found in this link as well.

The key word here is old backups & immediate access. Archive storage will take up to 4 hours to retrieve data, object storage will retrieve only latest copy. The logical answer here is block volume. D indeed makes sense here.
I go for B

Overview of Block Volume Backups
The backups feature of the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Block Volume service lets you make a point-in-time snapshot of the data on a block volume. You can make a backup of a volume when it is attached to an instance or while it is detached. These backups can then be restored to new volumes either immediately after a backup or at a later time that you choose.

Backups are encrypted and stored in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage, and can be restored as new volumes to any availability domain within the same region they are stored. This capability provides you with a spare copy of a volume and gives you the ability to successfully complete disaster recovery within the same region.

There are two ways you can initiate a backup, either by manually starting the backup, or by assigning a policy which defines a set backup schedule.

With block volume you have to provision the VM and also provide the (S)FTP or SCP to upload the files hence it's not fast setup.

questions.question_text: In what two ways does Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) offer industry leading price-performance? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B,C 
B - It's sort of obvious, that it is customer responsibility what to store. But as a proof take a look at the oracle provided chart about shared-security responsibilities: https://www.oracle.com/webfolder/s/assets/ebook/oracle-cloud-infrastructure-security/part3.html

C - Lets read what is Local NVMe and what is protected (source: https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/nvmedeviceinformation.htm). they are individual devices locally installed on your instance. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure does not take images, back up, or use RAID or any other methods to protect the data on NVMe devices. It is your responsibility to protect and manage the durability the data on these devices.

For sure A is incorrect. Object Storage is an OCI service and data durability inside that service is responsibility of Oracle.
BC is correct as Local NVMe data persistency is customer responsibility

“Oracle shares responsibility with you to ensure that the service is optimally configured and secured. This responsibility includes hypervisor security and the configuration of permissions and network access controls.”

B and C are the corect answers.

NVMe devices are not protected in any way; they are individual devices locally installed on your instance. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure does not take images, back up, or use RAID or any other methods to protect the data on NVMe devices. It is your responsibility to protect and manage the durability of the data on these devices.

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/nvmedeviceinformation.htm

A) can't be a correct answer since Object Storage data is stored redundantly across multiple storage servers which is by design. So a customer has no responsibility with Object Storage data durability. However the customer is responsible for securely configuring and managing your compute (virtual hosts, containers), storage (object, local storage, block volumes), and platform (database configuration) services.
